description:
Battus philenor, commonly known as the pipevine swallowtail, is a species of butterfly found in North America. It belongs to the family Papilionidae, which includes some of the largest and most distinctive butterflies.

The pipevine swallowtail is characterized by its distinctive black and iridescent blue-green wings, with a row of orange-red spots near the hindwing's outer edge. The larvae, or caterpillars, are primarily black with orange spots and are known to feed exclusively on plants in the Aristolochia genus, commonly referred to as pipevines.

The life cycle of the pipevine swallowtail involves complete metamorphosis, with the egg, larva, pupa, and adult stages. The adults use their long, coiled proboscis to feed on nectar from a variety of flowering plants, while the larvae utilize the toxic compounds found in their host plants to make themselves unpalatable to predators.

This species is known for its impressive migratory behavior, with some populations undertaking long-distance movements across North America. The pipevine swallowtail plays an important role in its ecosystem, serving as a pollinator and contributing to the overall biodiversity of the regions it inhabits.
